 Sakurai Gen'noshin Fumitake, who claimed to have been a very

r of the Shinsengumi.  Sakurai died at around the age of 100!

s a very interesting man and in the emails he sent to me many,

 ago he discussed many things most Japanese people of his

d not discuss in connection to WWII.

ant online bickering between his

nese martial arts which stems from
> ingrained attitudes concerning the dif=
ference between classical and modern

ognized it doesn't exist.  Teenager

ithmetic skills even ridiculed the
> possibility any member of the Shinseng=
umi living into the 20th century when
> in fact several did!  If they were =
just teenagers (remember in the 19th

ican community

ong the lines of

a sword---a western

     =
 
      
      <p>Many years back we mentioned Dr. Kotaka whose great-grand=
-uncle is Harada Sanosuke.=C2=A0 He also inherited the sword used by Harada=
.=C2=A0 Furthermore, Kotaka studied under Sakurai Gen'noshin Fumitake, =
who claimed to have been a very young member of the Shinsengumi.=C2=A0 Saku=
rai died at around the age of 100!=C2=A0 <br><br>Kotaka was a very interest=
ing man and in the emails he sent to me many, many years ago he discussed m=
any things most Japanese people of his generation would not discuss in conn=
ection to WWII.<br><br>What disappointed me was the constant online bickeri=
ng between his students and other practitioners of Japanese martial arts wh=
ich stems from ingrained attitudes concerning the difference between classi=
cal and modern lineages and if a lineage is not recognized it doesn't e=
xist.=C2=A0 Teenager stuff.=C2=A0 Some people who lack basic arithmetic ski=
lls even ridiculed the possibility any member of the Shinsengumi living int=
o the 20th century when in fact several did!=C2=A0 If they were just teenag=
ers (remember in the 19th century 12-14 year olds were treated like adults)=
 during the Bakumatsu Era they certainly lived well into the modern era.<br=
><br>Dr. Kotaka is well known to the Japanese and Japanese American communi=
ty and I smiled when I read a very old messageboard thread along the lines =
of "please stop slamming Dr. Kotaka---my sensei knows and respects him=
".=C2=A0 I connected with Dr. Kotaka during some research I did on a s=
word---a western practitioner made the referral.<br><br>Please read this <a=
 rel=3D"nofollow" href=3D"http://beisho.org/historical_13.html" target=3D"_=
blank">article</a>.<br>Then consider reading <a rel=3D"nofollow" href=3D"ht=
tp://www.amazon.com/Modern-day-Samurai-Sukesaburo-Minamoto-no-Appreciation/=
dp/1499715919" target=3D"_blank">this book</a>.=C2=A0 The comment in the re=
view section of the book is also worth your time.<br>  </p><p><br><span></s=
pan></p><p><span>Dr. Kotaka also invited me to his home.=C2=A0 <br></span><=
/p><p><span>Due to life circumstances there was no way I could make the tri=
p.</span></p><p><span>He was a walking time capsule.<br></span></p><p></p>
